properties.name: The Conviction Of Gun Dude
properties.description: Top down shoot'em up game with a leaderboard, randomized rooms, and upgrades.

events.comment: Click anywhere on scene to delete the reset button to start the timer.
If the reset button is deleted, start a timer to countdown for the scene transition.

content.text:
Hover over upgrade to see it's effect.

Move - WASD or Arrow keys
Dash - Space or Right mouse button
Shoot - Left mouse button

events.comment: When level starts, create 3 upgrade objects and apply effects.
Randomize the animation of, and apply effects to, each instance of the upgrade object.
When the player picks one of the upgrades, delete the other instances of the upgrade object.
Zoom and position camera of base layer to be align properly at the beginning of the scene.
Lerp camera to new room if player still exists and a new room is spawned.
If time is slowed to 0.05 for the room transitions, and when the camera gets within 5 pixels of the center of the new room, give player control back and set time scale to 1.(default)
While the camera transitions from the old room to the new one, apply a force to the player so they continue moving in to the room.
Walk during transitioning - Direction variable set when a new room is created by the player walking through a doorway.
Room Spawning - When the player walks off the floor object they're currently on, they trigger this event.
Going Upwards - Player enters the top doorway.
Going Down - Player enters the bottom doorway.
Going Left - Player enters the left doorway.
Going Right - Player enters the right doorway.
Create the set of room objects at the new point relative to the old room you were leaving.
Room Animation Picks - Randomized the room animation to pick a different room, then the doors and floor pick the same animation number.
Upgrade spawning - If one of the 2 blank rooms are picked instead of traps, create an upgrade object in the middle of the room, and apply effects.
Walk up variable being set, and stopping any dash - and returning the topdown behavior. (resetting a dash)
Enemy spawning - Pick all existing rooms, and then pick the new nearest floor to pick the new room. Then, if the player is alive, create enemy object at random points base on danger level variable.
Danger level 0-2 - Spawning just basic ghost enemies.
Danger level 3-6 - Spawning spiders and ghosts together.
Danger level 7-10+ - Spawning imps, spiders, and ghosts together.
Setting enemy health, multiplying their base health with the current rounded danger level.(Rounded to get Integers)
When a new room is created change the time scale during the transition.

Room Deleting- when you get a specified distance away from a Room, Roomfloor, or Roomtraps object - Delete that object.

This is both for performance, and to create a "shifting maze" effect, where there is no set level for the player to learn.
RoomDoors - When there are no enemies left on the map, set opacity to fade, and when the opacity hits 0, delete the room doors object.
Setting the z-order of all objects in the "Entities" object group to be equal to their Y position. Creating the fake depth of the top down game.
Setting the z-order of the player's gun to always be +1 above the player. So the gun stays in front of the player as the player's z-order shifts as they move around the scene.
Setting the z-order of all RoomFloor objects to be -3000 of their Y position. This is so the floor stays below all other object in the room.
Setting the z-order of the RoomTraps, again set well below their y position, to keep them below objects in the room.
Separate the player from the Room and RoomDoors so they can't leave the space they're in.
Position the player's gun to be at the "GunSpot" point set on the player object. And to rotate toward the mouse.
Flip the player object and gun relative to the position of the mouse compared to the player.
When the player object gets within 80 pixels of a PickUp object(score/health), the object has a force applied to move it towards the player.
Upon getting within 10 pixels of the player, the object is considered picked up. A sound is played, and a pitch variable increase, the next pick up will trigger using this new pitch variable.
If the object has the "HealthOrb" animation set, it'll delete and heal the player object for a percentage of their max health.

Change the width of the HealthBar, and the text of the HealthText by using the health variable in the "Health" behavior applied to the player object divided by the scene variable CharacterStats.Health which are acting as the current and maximum health for this game.
If the object has the "PointOrb" animation set, it'll delete and add 1 point to the PointCount scene variable.
If the player goes 1 full second without picking up a PickUp object, the pitch variable is returned to 1.(default)

If the player is in collision with an upgrade object, it applies an effect based on the animation the object had, and then deletes it. Afterward it creates an UpgradeIcons object at a position below the health bar, using the latest created UpgradeIcons to know where to place the next upgrade.
Health - Adds 3 to the CharacterStats.Health scene variable. (Which changes the maximum amount HealthOrb PickUp objects can health to)

Change the width of the HealthBar, and the text of the HealthText by using the health variable in the "Health" behavior applied to the player object divided by the scene variable CharacterStats.Health which are acting as the current and maximum health for this game.
Armor - Adds 2 to the CharacterStats.Defense scene variable. (Which is used when a GhostOrb collides with the player)
FireRate - Multiplies the CharacterStats.FireRate scene variable by 0.85. (Which is used in the firerate timer event for shooting)
Power - Adds 2 to the CharacterStats.Power scene variable. (Which is used when a bullet collides with an enemy)
Speed - Adds to the player object's maximum speed, and adds 1 to the CharacterStats.Speedcap scene variable. (Which is used to deminish the effectiveness of subsequent speed upgrades)
Upgrade Icon Display - Create an upgrade icon at a position relative to the number of icons on screen and then change it's animation to match the upgrade you're interacting with.
Finally, delete the upgrades object after the upgrade effect has been applied.
If the player isn't in the middle of a transition event between two rooms, allow the sub events to happen.
Starting an object timer "Dash" for the player, to be used in events later. Events like when to take damage, and when you're able to dash again.
Dash event - When the player is moving, pressing the space bar OR the right mouse button will cause them to dash.

If their Dash boolean variable is false, they'll begin to dash, moving the top down controls from the player for the duration of the dash and applying a force(angle) in the direction they were moving.

During the dash(Boolean is true) 
if the dash timer is below 0.2 seconds, the dash particle will follow the players position.
if the dash timer is above 0.2 seconds, all forces to the player object are stopped, and the top down behavior is reactivated.
At 0.5 seconds of the dash timer, while the dash boolean is true, the boolean is set back to false so the player can dash again.
Change the animation of the player object to Run/Idle based on conditions from the top down behavior.
If the W or Up keys are pressed, simulate the Up key being pressed, for the top down behavior.
If the A or Left keys are pressed, simulate the Left key being pressed, for the top down behavior.
If the D or Right keys are pressed, simulate the Right key being pressed, for the top down behavior.
If the S or Down keys are pressed, simulate the Down key being pressed, for the top down behavior.
Create the time "FireRate" at the beginning of the scene to be used for the firerate related events below.

When the FireRate time is above the scene variable CharacterStats.FireRate and the left mouse button is down, create a bullet and add a force(Angle) in the direction the gun was pointing.

And apply the game juice related effects, like screenshake and creating a particle at the BulletSpawn point.

If the recoil timer is below 0.1 seconds long, an instant force is applied to the character using the angle saved to the object variable of the player "RecoilAngle" during the bullet firing event above.
Deleting stray bullets if they collide with a room wall or the room doors during combat.

If the player collides with a GhostOrb or the RoomTraps object, and they are no currently flashing(Flash/Blink behavior) then apply effects and damage the player object based on the game's current DangerLevelRounded value subtracted by the player's armor value which is the scene variable CharacterStats.Defense.

Change the width of the HealthBar, and the text of the HealthText by using the health variable in the "Health" behavior applied to the player object divided by the scene variable CharacterStats.Health which are acting as the current and maximum health for this game.
If the player's health reaches 0(Or below) they are deleted from the game to remove control and trigger the game restart events.
If the player's X position is greater/less than that of the enemy's in the "enemy" object group, they'll turn to face the player's position.

Separate all enemies from the Room object, and then separate all imp and spider objects from the RoomTraps object.

This excludes the ghosts so they can float over the traps and not get displaced.
Separate all Ghosts, Spiders, and Imps from one another so they aren't spawning on top of one another at the beginning of a new room.
The Ghost will Idle if they're above 120 pixels away from the player object, at which point their opacity changes to 100 and they have a force applied toward the player positon.
If the ghost was hit and had its animation changed to "Hurt", when that animation finishes it will change to the Idle animation.
If the ghost was playing the Idle animation, and is below 120 pixels away from the player, it will change it's animation to "Charging", and set it's opacity to 255.
Shooting - When the Charging animation is finished, it will change the animation to "resting", and create a GhostOrb object and apply a permanent force toward the player's position.

If the ghost animation is set to Resting, and the animation is finished, change the animation to Idle.

This acts as the "gap" that makes the ghost wait before firing another shot.
If The Ghost object's opacity is 255(not transparent) and they collide with a bullet object, they'll change to the "Hurt" animation and have the below actions applied to them for effect.
If the object timer "Knockback" of the Ghost is below 0.1 seconds, an instant force is applied towards the angle saved when the bullet collided with the ghost in the above event.
The Spider will Idle if they're above 15 pixels away from the player object, at which point they have a force applied toward the player positon.
If the spider was hit and had its animation changed to "Hurt", when that animation finishes it will change to the Idle animation.
If the spider was playing the Idle animation, and is below 15 pixels away from the player, it will change it's animation to "Charging".
Shooting - When the Charging animation is finished, it will change the animation to "resting", and create a grouping of GhostOrb objects and apply a permanent force toward the player's position.

If the spider animation is set to Resting, and the animation is finished, change the animation to Idle.

This acts as the "gap" that makes the spider wait before firing another shot.
If The spider object collides with a bullet object, they'll change to the "Hurt" animation and have the below actions applied to them for effect.
If the object timer "Knockback" of the spider is below 0.1 seconds, an instant force is applied towards the angle saved when the bullet collided with the spider in the above event.
The Imp will Idle if they're above 140 pixels away from the player object, at which point they have a force applied toward the player positon.
If the Imp was playing the Idle animation, and is below 140 pixels away from the player, it will change it's animation to "Charging".

Shooting - When the Charging animation is finished, it will change the animation to "resting", and create a spray of GhostOrb objects and apply a permanent force toward a set angle relative to the player.

This first creates the spread variable for the imp and sets it to 130. Then with each time the below event repeats it adds 10 degrees to the spread variable. Causing 9 different GhostOrb objects to spawn and spread outwards with 10 degrees difference between each angle of fire.

If the Imp animation is set to Resting, and the animation is finished, change the animation to Idle.

This acts as the "gap" that makes the Imp wait before firing another shot.
If The Imp object collides with a bullet object, they'll have the below actions applied to them for effect.(The Imp does not have a "hurt" animation)
If the object timer "Knockback" of the spider is below 0.1 seconds, an instant force is applied towards the angle saved when the bullet collided with the spider in the above event.

If the "Enemies" health drops to 0 or below, pick a random integer in the range of 0-100 and then check to see if that integer is below the drop chance variable set for the enemy object, and if it is create a PickUp object and change it's animation to "HealthOrb". Then based on the drop amount variable, set for the enemy object, create a PickUp object to represent point pick ups.

Apply a permanent force to the created PickUp Objects at a random float in range of 0-360 degrees, and begin a timer for each to track how long they've been moving for.
Delete stray GhostOrbs if they collide with the Room or RoomDoors
If the object timer of a "PickUp" object is above 0.2 seconds, stop all forces.(Ending their movement after killing an enemy)
If the object timer of a "PickUp" object is above 5 seconds, delete it.(Performance saving, but also encouraging the player to pick up the object before they disappear)
Applying to all EnemyDamageText objects on screen, change their opacity by an amount multiplied by TimeDelta()
When their opacity does reach 0, delete the enemyDamageText object.
Hide the Reset_Timer object, so it can be shown later when needed.
This event will only trigger if the player object is deleted, showing the Reset layer, and allowing for the buttons to be pressed.
Create a "Death" timer, which gives a 1.5 second window for the player to realize they've died before the Reset layer is shown.
when the "Death" timer is above 1.5 seconds, show the Reset layer and align objects to fit the screen, and apply effects.(Like object shake)
If the Reset layer is visible, but the Leaderboard layer isn't, allow the subevents to trigger.
If the mouse is hovering over the Reset button, and the left mouse button is released, delete the button objects and restart the "Death" timer.
If the buttons were deleted by the above event, check the "Death" timer and apply the changes to the newly shown "Reset_timer" object.
If the mouse is hovering over the leaderboard text object and the left mouse button is released, delete the text objects and show the leaderboard layer and apply tweaks.
If the leaderboard layer is visible, align the text input object and the submit text object with the screen width.
If the text input object is clicked in to, or focused, they submit button will become visible again.(Encouraging the player to put a name in first)

If the submit button is visible, and the mouse button is hovered over them, and the left moiuse button is release, send the scene variable "PointCount" to the selected leaderboard with the player name typed in to the LeaderboardNameinput object.
When the leaderboard has finished leading, pause this scene and start the "lLeaderboard" scene.

This event sends the player back to the previously paused scene when the leaderboard is exited from.

This acts as a "pause" for the game to prevent anything in game from being interacted with while the leaderboard is showing on top of your game.

Change the width of the HealthBar, and the text of the HealthText by using the health variable in the "Health" behavior applied to the player object divided by the scene variable CharacterStats.Health which are acting as the current and maximum health for this game.

The 216 value for the healthbar width changing action is the size of the healthbar in pixels when at fully health. Changing the width relative to 216 will display the % of the health that is remaining.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Tristan Rhodes (tristan@victrisgames.com)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
Useful to make a temporary effect (flash on hit, flickering lights, lightning flash, show text like Batman and Robin "Bam!", etc)

It is recommended to select a layer on the top, and one that is hidden by default.
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: FlashLayer
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Make a layer visible for a specified duration, and then hide the layer.

eventsFunctions.description: Make a layer visible for a specified duration, and then hide the layer.
eventsFunctions.name: FlashLayer

events.comment: Save input parameters
Set default values
Start timer and show layer
Hide layer, reset time-scale to initial value, and delete timer

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @4ian
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description: Add actions and conditions to manage the life of the object. Object can get damages, lose some health and you can check with a condition if it's dead.
eventsFunctionsExtensions.fullName: Health (life points and damages for objects)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Health
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Add actions and conditions to manage the life of the object. Object can get damages, lose some health and you can check with a condition if it's dead.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Add actions and conditions to manage the life of the object. Object can get damages, lose some health and you can check with a condition if it's dead.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: Health

eventsFunctions.description: Add some damage to the object, decreasing its life.
eventsFunctions.name: Hit

parameters.description: Value of the damage to do (will be removed from object health)
parameters.name: DamageValue

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the object is considered dead (no more health).
eventsFunctions.name: IsDead

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the object was just damaged previously in the events.
eventsFunctions.name: IsJustDamaged

eventsFunctions.description: Heal the object, incrasing its life.
eventsFunctions.name: Heal

parameters.description: How much to heal (will be added to object health)
parameters.name: HealValue

eventsFunctions.description: Change the object health to set it to a specific value (check if the actions to damage or heal the object are not better suited to your use case before using this one).
eventsFunctions.name: SetHealth

propertyDescriptors.label: Damage cooldown (in seconds) (0 for no cooldown)
propertyDescriptors.name: DamageCooldown

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @4ian
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
Make the object flash (blink) for a period of time, so that it is alternately visible and invisible.
After adding this to an object, you have to **trigger the effect** by using the **Flash action**.
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Flash
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription:
Make the object flash (blink) for a period of time, so that it is alternately visible and invisible.
Trigger the effect by using the Flash action.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description:
Make the object flash (blink) for a period of time, so that it is alternately visible and invisible.
Trigger the effect by using the Flash action.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: Flash

eventsFunctions.description: Make the specified object(s) blink for the given duration.
eventsFunctions.name: Flash

parameters.description: Duration of the blinking, in seconds
parameters.name: FlashDuration

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the specified objects are flashing.
eventsFunctions.name: IsFlashing

eventsFunctions.description: Stop the flashing of the specified object.
eventsFunctions.name: Stop

propertyDescriptors.label: Half period (time during which object is invisible), in seconds
propertyDescriptors.name: HalfPeriodTime

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Tristan Rhodes (https://victrisgames.itch.io/)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
Select one or more methods of shaking:
- Position: Shake the X and/or Y position of the object 
- Angle: Shake the angle (rotation) of the object 
- Scale: Shake the scale of the object (must be a sprite)

Control how the object shakes:
- Amplitude: How far the object moves during each shake
- Duration: Amount of time to shake the object
- Time between shakes: Amount of time between each movement of the object
- Keep shaking until stopped (boolean)

Tips:
- For a single-shake effect, set the "Time between shakes" to be equal to "Duration"  (great for a hit or impact)
- To make the single-shake move in the opposite direction, use negative numbers 
- To repeat a single-shake effect in a loop, add a condition "Object is not shaking" 
- Use a long "Time between shakes" to simulate a slow moving object (like a ship rocking back and forth)
- Make sure to "Stop shaking" before starting a new shake if it uses different parameters. 
- Use "Shake until stopped" to simulate engine vibration, earthquake, or pulsing
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: ShakeObject
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Shake an object, using one or more ways to shake (position, angle, scale).

eventsBasedBehaviors.description:
Shake an object, using one or more ways to shake (position, angle).
This behavior can be used on any type of object.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: ShakeObject_PositionAngle

eventsFunctions.description: Shake an object, using one or more ways to shake (position, angle).
eventsFunctions.name: ShakeObject_PositionAngle
eventsFunctions.sentence: Shake object _PARAM0_ for _PARAM2_ seconds. Modify position amplitude _PARAM3_ on X axis and _PARAM4_ on Y axis, angle rotation amplitude _PARAM5_.  Wait _PARAM6_ seconds between shakes. Keep shaking until stopped: _PARAM7_

events.comment: Start/Reset duration timer
Pass input parameters to global variables so that onScenePostEvents can use them
Determine if the shake should keep going until stopped
Add default values if none were provided
If duration is less than a single shake, increase duration to make 1 full shake
Detect initial shake
Initiate the onScenePostEvents function

parameters.description: Amplitude of postion shake in X direction (in pixels)  (For example: 5)
parameters.name: PowerX

parameters.description: Amplitude of position shake in Y direction (in pixels)  (For example: 5)
parameters.name: PowerY

parameters.description: Amplitude of angle rotation shake (in degrees)  (For example: 5)
parameters.name: PowerAngle

parameters.description: Amount of time between shakes (in seconds) (Default: 0.08)
parameters.name: TimeBetweenShakes

events.comment: Keep object shaking forever (if desired)
Run once before every shake movement

events.name: Correct for drift and reset drift tracking variables

events.comment: Move to correct any drift from previous shake
Reset drift detection variables
Calculate Position Shake
PositionDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude * [-1 or 1]
Make initial shake NOT random so users can set a direction for a one-shake effect
After initial shake pick a random direction
Calculate Rotation (angle) shake
Every "even" shake, rotate clockwise
AngleDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude
Every "odd" shake, rotate counter-clockwise
AngleDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude
Save that initial shake has been processed
Calculate the fraction of shake that occured during this frame
Increase change for the first half of the shake (move away from original values)
Change position
Save movement to calculate drift
Change angle
Save movement to calculate drift
Decrease change the second half of the shake (return to original position)
Change position
Save movement to calculate drift
Change angle
Save movement to calculate drift
Stop shaking when the duration has been reached (or if the stop shaking function was called)

events.name: Correct for drift and reset drift tracking variables

events.comment: Move to correct any drift from previous shake
Reset drift detection variables

eventsFunctions.description: Stop any shaking of object that was initiated by the Shake Object extension.
eventsFunctions.name: StopShaking

eventsFunctions.description: Check if an object is shaking.
eventsFunctions.fullName: Check if an object is shaking
eventsFunctions.name: IsShaking

eventsBasedBehaviors.description:
Shake an object, using one or more ways to shake (position, angle, scale)
This behavior can only be used on sprite objects.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: ShakeObject_PositionAngleScale

eventsFunctions.description: Shake an object, using one or more ways to shake (position, angle, scale).
eventsFunctions.name: ShakeObject_PositionAngleScale
eventsFunctions.sentence: Shake object _PARAM0_ for _PARAM2_ seconds. Modify position amplitude _PARAM3_ on X axis and _PARAM4_ on Y axis, angle rotation amplitude _PARAM5_, and scale amplitude _PARAM6_.  Wait _PARAM7_ seconds between shakes.  Keep shaking until stopped: _PARAM8_

events.comment: Start/Reset duration timer
Pass input parameters to global variables so that onScenePostEvents can use them
Determine if the shake should keep going until stopped
Add default values if none were provided
If duration is less than a single shake, increase duration to make 1 full shake
Detect initial shake
Initiate the onScenePostEvents function

parameters.description: Amplitude of postion shake in X direction (in pixels)  (For example: 5)
parameters.name: PowerX

parameters.description: Amplitude of position shake in Y direction (in pixels)  (For example: 5)
parameters.name: PowerY

parameters.description: Amplitude of angle rotation shake (in degrees)  (For example: 5)
parameters.name: PowerAngle

parameters.description: Amplitude of scale shake (in percent change)  (For example: 5)
parameters.name: PowerScale

parameters.description: Amount of time between shakes (in seconds) (Default: 0.08)
parameters.name: TimeBetweenShakes

events.comment: Keep object shaking forever (if desired)
Run once before every shake movement

events.name: Correct for drift and reset drift tracking variables

events.comment: Move to correct any drift from previous shake
Reset drift detection variables
Calculate Position Shake
PositionDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude * [-1 or 1]
Make initial shake NOT random so users can set a direction for a one-shake effect
After initial shake pick a random direction
Calculate Rotation (angle) shake
Every "even" shake, rotate clockwise
AngleDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude
Every "odd" shake, rotate counter-clockwise
AngleDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude
Calculate Scale shake
Calculate object scale displacement, with linear decay over time
ScaleDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude *  1/100
Every even shake, increase scale
Every "odd" shake, decrease scale
ScaleDisplacement = -1 * (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude *  1/100
Save that initial shake has been processed
Calculate the fraction of shake that occured during this frame
Increase change for the first half of the shake (move away from original values)
Change position
Save movement to calculate drift
Change angle
Save movement to calculate drift
Change scale
Save movement to calculate drift
Decrease change the second half of the shake (return to original position)
Change position
Save movement to calculate drift
Change angle
Save movement to calculate drift
Change scale
Save movement to calculate drift
Stop shaking when the duration has been reached (or if the stop shaking function was called)

events.comment: Move to correct any drift from previous shake
Reset drift detection variables

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: westboy31, Tristan Rhodes (https://victrisgames.itch.io/)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
Ideal for explosions, hit/impacts, earthquake, etc.

Select one or more methods of shaking:
- Position:  Shake the X and/or Y position of the camera 
- Angle: Shake the rotation of the camera 
- Zoom: Shake the zoom level of the camera 

Control how the camera shakes:
- Amplitude: How far the camera moves during each shake
- Duration: Amount of time to shake the camera
- Time between shakes: Amount of time between each change of the movement of the camera
- Keep shaking until stopped (boolean)

Tips:
- For a single-shake effect, set the "Time between shakes" to be equal to "Duration"  (great for a hit or impact)
- To make the single-shake move in the opposite direction, use negative numbers 
- To repeat a single-shake effect in a loop, add a condition "Camera is not shaking" 
- Use a long "Time between shakes" to simulate a slow moving object (like a ship rocking back and forth)
- Make sure to "Stop shaking" before starting a new shake if it uses different parameters. 
- Use "Shake until stopped" to simulate engine vibration, earthquake, or pulsing
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: CameraShake
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Shake the camera on the specified layer using one or more methods of shaking (position, angle, zoom).

eventsFunctions.description: Shake the camera on the specified layer, using one or more ways to shake (position, angle, zoom).
eventsFunctions.name: CameraShake
eventsFunctions.sentence: Shake camera on _PARAM3_ layer for _PARAM5_ seconds. Use an amplitude of _PARAM1_px on X axis and _PARAM2_px on Y axis, angle rotation amplitude _PARAM6_ degrees, and zoom amplitude _PARAM7_ percent.  Wait _PARAM8_ seconds between shakes. Keep shaking until stopped: _PARAM9_

events.comment: Start/Reset duration timer
Pass input parameters to global variables so that onScenePostEvents can use them
Determine if the shake should keep going until stopped
Add default values if none were provided
If duration is less than a single shake, increase duration to make 1 full shake
Detect initial shake
Initiate the onScenePostEvents function

parameters.description: Amplitude of shaking on the X axis (pixels) (For example: 5)
parameters.name: PowerX

parameters.description: Amplitude of shaking on the Y axis (pixels) (For example: 5)
parameters.name: PowerY

events.comment: Keep shaking forever (if desired)
Run once before every shake movement

events.name: Correct for drift and reset drift tracking variables

events.comment: Move to correct any drift from previous shake
Reset drift detection variables
Calculate Position Shake
PositionDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude * [-1 or 1]
Make initial shake NOT random so users can set a direction for a one-shake effect
After initial shake pick a random direction
Calculate Rotation (angle) shake
Every "even" shake, rotate counter-clockwise
DisplacementAngle = ((DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration) * Amplitude
Every "odd" shake, rotate clockwise (this includes the initial shake and can be used for a one shake effect)
DisplacementAngle = -1 * ((DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration) * Amplitude
Calculate Zoom shake
Calculate camera zoom displacement, with linear decay over time
ZoomDisplacement = ((DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration) * Amplitude *  1/100
Every even shake, increase zoom
Every "odd" shake, decrease scale
ZoomDisplacement = -1 * ((DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration) * Amplitude *  1/100
Save that initial shake has been processed
Calculate the fraction of shake that occured during this frame
Increase change for the first half of the shake (move away from original values)
Change position
Save movement to calculate drift
Change angle
Save movement to calculate drift
Change zoom
Save movement to calculate drift
Decrease change the second half of the shake (return to original position)
Change position
Save the amount of change to calculate drift
Change angle
Save the amount of change to calculate drift
Change zoom
Save the amount of change to calculate drift
Stop shaking when the duration has been reached or if stop shaking has been requested

events.name: Correct for drift and reset drift tracking variables

events.comment: Move to correct drift from previous shake
Reset drift detection variables
